column1: Before 1 September 2022, will Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan sign an agreement governing the filling of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) reservoir?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Still a long way from an agreement.
Repeating my forecast. Ethiopia is moving forward, with no negotiations in sight.https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/ethiopia-completes-third-phase-filling-giant-nile-dam-2022-08-12/
@iibrahim seems to have a sound explanation.
Incredibly unlikely.
It’s got too much existential significance for them to be able to compromise and settle in a politically acceptable way.
Never put frogs in boiling water!

https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2022/05/egypt-ethiopia-compete-us-support-nile-dam-file Ethiopia has appointed their water minister as ambo to the United States, so clearly wish to resist any diplomatic pressure to arrive at a formal agreement on the issue
Seems dead in the… water. Pun not intended.
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/sudan-pushes-for-new-methodology-for-nile-dam-talks/2207685 No change
Five Observations
https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2022/03/new-consultations-over-nile-dam-inspire-optimism-sudan

Decreasing the probability as there has been no progress recently. That said I am holding significantly above average as I think increasing world conflict will bring about the importance of irrigation water.
https://theconversation.com/nile-basin-at-a-turning-point-as-ethiopian-dam-starts-operations-178267
Discussion has been going on for ages
Now that the dam has started generating electricity, there isn't much reason for Ethiopia to agree to anything.

Ethiopia has already started using the GERD, which gives them a bit of an upper hand in the timeline of the negotiation process. Link to Al Ahram here https://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/461344/Egypt/Politics-/Ethiopia-to-generate-electricity-from-GERD-startin.aspx
having come out of a state of emergency early perhaps they have the energy to do some diplomatic house cleaning?

Construction started about 10 years ago, and nothing signed to date... Ethiopia have started filling anyway - so it's not even like they need to wait. Moreover, civil war in Ethiopia, Coup in Sudan, so probably not that high priority for two of the three parties
There is no incentive for any of these countries to work together. Meanwhile, Ethiopia and Sudan have bigger civil conflicts to worry about.

The civil war in Ethiopia is unfortunately getting worse, and Sudan just had a coup, so I think there is most likely too much instability for a GERD agreement to be signed between Ethiopia, Sudan, and Egypt by Sept 1st 2022.
My real forecast is 1%, but I'm raising it to 5% as part of a Brier destruction prevention program, because I could be wrong.

I previously forecast this as a 55% for Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan signing an agreement. However, I am lowering that forecast to 30% after reading some additional information cited by @craigda007 on this question about the internal conflict in Tigray, Ethiopia and the tension it is causing with Sudan (https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/conflict-ethiopia). This really complicates the situation. If the time horizon were less than a year, my forecast would be lower. But, I will stick with 30% or about a 1 in 3 chance given there is almost 10 months before this question closes.

Useful and excellent base rate from @Srwade9 of 80%. I share sentiments of unfavourability with the following: Reduce 10% - tensions remain high and diplomatic procedures thus far unsuccessful through African Union. Reduce 10% - Unaddressed by UN Security Council driving Nation-state diplomacy which is erratic and unproductive. Reduce 15% - Ethiopia maintaining a nationalism view and aspirations for internal economic development in water-dependent economy Reduce 10% - Ethiopia conflict in Tigray

Support for: The dam is nearly full and is, or will soon be, producing power. The status quo has changed: The dam exists, regardless of Egypt's and Sudan's feelings and regardless of previous Nile Water agreements that did not include Ethiopia. The dam is located within Etiopia and it is fully within Ethiopia's rights to build and reap the benefits of a dam on its territory. It is in the best interest of the three countries to come to an agreement to ensure their water needs are met and to provide a venue for disagreements for they are sure to come up. In addition, the dam can help reduce the damaging effects of seasonal floods and introduce a third farming season into all three countries.

My starting point looking at historical data shows that 4 out 5 instances (or 80% of the time) in the last 50 years, nations that share transboundary water resources have come to an agreement (37 violent clashes/disputes out of 187 similar situations as noted by the UN at https://www.un.org/waterforlifedecade/transboundary_waters.shtml). However, I am less optimistic in this situation given that the three nations involved have had since 2011 when construction began on the GERD to come to an agreement. As well, Ethiopia has now completed two rainy seasons where the reservoir was filled and 2022 will bring the final rainy season required to complete the filling process. Officials at Sudan’s Al-Rusaires Dam, only 100km from the GERD, reported that they have not observed reductions in the flow of the Nile River even while the second reservoir filling was underway (https://www.newsday.co.zw/2021/07/sudan-says-nile-water-level-stable-despite-ethiopias-2nd-filling-of-nile-dam/#:~:text=The%20Al-Rusaires%20Dam%20on%20the%20Blue%20Nile%2C%20which,to%20the%20filling%20and%20operation%20of%20the%20GERD.) To me this fact reduces the pressure on even coming to an agreement at all between the three nations, especially by the 1 Sep 2022 timeframe as the question is written. However, one thing that still keeps my forecast on the plus side of 50% is that the closer the deadline looms for the final filling of the reservoir, more pressure will be felt and exerted for the three nations to come to an agreement. Then again, a serious complication to the negotiations is the inclusion of overall Nile Water Quotas in the discussions about the GERD which have been in place since 1959. That may mean that a final agreement will simply take longer to reach than in the next year.

Six years of agreements haven't produced anything, and Ethiopia is embroiled in conflict over Tigray. I'd have put only 5%, but after last week 95% confidence is a LOT higher range than it feels like at first.

There seems, as our colleague @Okanaganopolis points out, no serious need for such an agreement on the part of Ethiopia and apparently also no practical way to prevent their doing as they please. Not going all the way to zero, just in case something comes up.
A concise 360 degree visual tour from dam to Egypt with the BBC in 2018 provides a starter for me: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53432948

"When the filling stage is over, Ethiopia is reluctant to be tied to a figure of how much water to release. Its priority will be to make sure there is enough water to operate what will become the largest hydroelectric plant in Africa." This indicate no agreement on working the matter through formal agreement yet https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53432948

Although negotiations among the three countries was facilitated by US and in the presence of the President of the World Bank (WB) starting from end of 2019 until 2020. and rules concerning mechanism of operating the dam and the filling process of the reservoir during the drought still an agreement was not sealed yet for a situation running since 2011. https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/105925/We-won-t-settle-until-legal-binding-agreement-is-reached https://www.brookings.edu/blog/africa-in-focus/2020/08/05/the-controversy-over-the-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam/

Ethiopia likes the present agreement and changing it to some kind of binding process will weaken their position. Sudan has reported no decrease in flow during the second filling. The UN security council is not getting actively involved. All of these point to no agreement. The wild card is what happens if flow is impacted and how serious is Egypt's threat of military action?

As one of the poorest countries in the World, Ethiopia needs the electrification as supplied by the Nile Dam to create an infrastructure for the country. Egypt and the Sudan who rely on the Nile waters for their needs are relying on traditional water rites. The Egyptian President, Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi, made a strategic mistake by signing a Declaration of Principles that gave Ethiopia carte blanche to control the Nile waters and believes that another agreement is not necessary. Unfortunately, the Declaration did not allow for any mechanism to resolve any future disputes. Negotiations have stalled, due in the opinion of Egyptian and Sudanese officials, the lack of Ethiopian seriousness in concluding talks in a bid to buy time to complete the filling of the dam. There is little leverage that can be applied to persuade Ethiopia to comply with the wishes of Egypt and the Sudan. Ethiopia’s major trading partners are the U.S., Saudi Arabia, U.A.E. and Israel, none of which are affected by the dam and its economics. The U.N Security council issued a Presidential statement calling for resumption of talks led by the African Union (AU), although India later stated that ‘as a general rule, transboundary water issues do not belong to the domain of the UN Security Council’. The Egyptian Ambassador to the U.N. did not object to Ethiopia’s right, but considering the existential threats to his country, the Egyptians should defend their right to life. This potential threat may have perhaps been for his domestic consumption but would indicate a possible escalation of hostile intentions. Sudan’s Irrigation Minister Yasser Abbas described negotiations in the current are a ‘waste of time’ and wants to involve the AU, UN, EU and the US. (This has been refused by Ethiopia, not to mention the distance effected by all the other parties).

Disputes over Nile River water are only going to heat up with population growth and climate change. This is but one part. Ethiopia has the upper hand because they're upstream, but Egypt and Sudan can cause problems for Ethiopia. I can picture the situation festering for years without any formal agreement and potentially coming to a head during the next substantial drought, during which time Ethiopia could potentially exact concessions in return for the release of some water. No, Ethiopia isn't going to come to the table to talk because this reservoir is a source of power for them, literally and figuratively, in addition to being central to their water security. They haven't come to an agreement about GERD in a decade. What's going to change now? I also appreciate and agree with the analysis by @AimadEO.
The Ethiopians are famous for their willingness to "go it alone" and stand up against international pressure, across diverse governments over many decades, if not centuries.

An armed confrontation between Egypt and Ethiopia over the matter is more likely than a treaty settling the issue. Egypt is just too stubborn and will not bulge, keeping their position and wanting to keep the current agreement in place (the one from 1929). Meanwhile, Ethiopia also remains unlikely to concede to Egyptian demands, and will continue pushing its plans forward. So... yeagh.
#JGS reminder30
